text:
ROBYN WOODMAN: Good morning
from Stanford to wherever you are in the world. Thank you for being here
today part of the women Rise

Community I'm Robyn
Woodman, and I am here with Dr. Sheri Sheppard.

Thank you for being here today SHERI SHEPPARD: It's
good to be here. ROBYN WOODMAN: She is
a Professor Emerita of the mechanical engineering
department here at Stanford.

And her building is just
right across the street. So this is really nice. SHERI SHEPPARD: We're neighbors. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. We're doing something a little
bit fun today, where we're

going to be in the same room. Thank you for being here. SHERI SHEPPARD: Great. ROBYN WOODMAN: And she's going
to talk to us about her journey

up, the obstacles
that she had in making tenured professor, some of,
maybe, the traps that she

had to overcome. And I like to call it the
story behind the story. And it's always so nice when
people can come and share

that with us. So thank you so much
for being here today. SHERI SHEPPARD: Thank you Robyn. And it's great to be here. But I actually want
to actually be here.

So I'm going to ask all of
you to indulge me as we start. And I'd like all
of you to be here. And I suspect that you've
had a busy morning.

You've maybe had
several meetings, maybe you've gotten
kids off to school. So indulge me in helping
me do some big breathing.

So get comfortable, maybe put
your feet flat on the floor. And we're going to do some
[NON-ENGLISH] breathing.

So let's all take
a big breath in.
A big breath out. Let's do two more. Big breath in.
Big breath out.
In.  Out.

Thank you. Now I feel like I'm here, Robyn. ROBYN WOODMAN: Awesome. Thank you. SHERI SHEPPARD: So it is
really great to be here

to talk a little bit about
this idea of being alone, or are you alone in your
work, and the Yes trap.

So those are the
two themes that I'm hoping we'll have
some time to discuss. And I urge you as I go along,
if you've got questions

or you've got comments,
please add them in the chat that is
available to you.

So in some ways, my career
has been very much alone. For 18 years, I was the
only woman professor

on the faculty from 1986. And then 18 years
later, we finally hired another woman
to be on the team.

And now we actually have
seven women on the faculty. In most of my engineering
classes in the 1970s,

I was the only
woman in the class, and I never had a female
professor in any of my math

or engineering courses. And I could focus
on that, but I'm not going to because I'm
going to really talk

about some strategies
of getting through that. I would say, when
I enter a room,

I still, though, look around
and scan who's in the room, and how many women are at the
table, how many people of color

are at the table, how many
people with disabilities. So that issue of, how
do we increase diversity

and a sense of
belonging, are still very much part of
my personal agenda, but also my professional agenda.

So I'm going to talk about this
process of not feeling alone by team building.

And so I'd like to
introduce you to three of the teams that have been
particularly important to me

along the way. And I hope that as I talk
about this idea of a team that gets you thinking about,
whose team are you on,

or who's on your team in these
three particular categories.

And so first, I'd like to
introduce you to this team. And you'll see three
characters here.

This is Mrs. Miller
this is Homer Sheppard. And this is Professor Corregian. And they are--

I'll call them team career. And let me tell you a little bit
of the stories of these three

people. So Mrs. Miller was
my violin teacher from the time I was in seventh
grade until 12th grade.

And from her, I
really learned what it is to work hard, what does
it mean to take something

that at first you're
not very good at, and then work, and work,
and work, with feedback

on getting better at it. And I think that was the
first time I recognized that being good at something
isn't just a natural act,

you're not just born
knowing how to do something. But with direction
and dedication,

you can get good at something. And that was actually
a very prideful field that I was good at something.

It also set my sights on maybe
being a professional musician as a career, and
what would it be

like to play Bach, or Beethoven,
or Brahms, in Carnegie Hall. And I have to say,
I was also drawn

to the idea of being able
to wear elegant gowns and have fancy hairdos, and that
that could be my career path.

So Mrs. Miller was
key in many ways in thinking about
my career team.

The second person
is Homer Sheppard, who happens to be my father. And he is an engineer--
oh, he was an engineer.

He passed away a few years ago. And he influenced me because I
really admired how he thought.

A problem would come
up in the house, and it could be a broken
dishwasher or a dilemma

in the yard, and his
approach wasn't to panic, it was maybe to
say a swear word.

But then he really
got into a strategy of decomposing what was wrong--

might be happening. At that point I said,
engineering, though, is not for me.

My dad worked in a foundry. And if you visited
a foundry, it's a very noisy, messy,
hot, sweaty environment,

certainly not where you
could wear elegant gowns. And so I really wasn't
thinking about engineering.

But I did admire and start to
recognize that ways of thinking are important, and engineering
had something to it.

So that's the second
person on my team. The third is a
professor Corregian

who was one of my
professors when I was working on my master's
degree in engineering. So somehow, I did pivot
from music to engineering.

And I was working on this
master's because I thought it was a step to becoming a CEO
of Chrysler Corporation, where

I happened to be an
engineer at the time. And really seeing more
technical depth was important.

I was also thinking about
enrolling in an MBA program, thinking, again, if you want
to rise in an organization,

you need to understand and
even more than the technical about what a business is. And I saw in Professor
Corregian someone

who was so dedicated to
his mission of teaching. And he wasn't simply
going into a classroom

and delivering
material to people, but in fact, he was
making that material come alive to individuals.

And so it really planted
the seed of saying, are there other ways for me to
be in the world besides being

a CEO of a company? He took me under his wing
in terms of helping me write

or co-authoring with me
my first technical paper. And he suggested, oh, they
need some teachers at night

at Lawrence Institute
of Technology, you might be good at teaching. And so he put that seed in me
of thinking about teaching.

So I won't tell you how
that mix of that team came together in my mind at
various stages of my career

to influence where I ended up
being for the last 36 years, but I will leave you with
a little teaser about team

career, and that's Gertrude. So Gertrude is a
member of my life.

And I can tell you
the story of Gertrude and the role that
she's playing or how I'm playing her in my life
now, even though I'm not

a professional musician. So that's the first team. The second team I'd like
to talk with you about is--

well, actually, one of the
things to leave you with too is you thinking about who
is own your career team,

and how has that
changed over the years, and what has been the
influence of those individuals

as you think about steps
or stages of your career. So my next team is
the team, you go girl.

And members of that team are
grandma Jo, grandma Whittaker,

and Simona Frank. And so let me tell you the
stories of grandma Joe, grandma Whittaker, and Simona Frank.

And I would say, as a team,
they really illustrated to me there's no one way
to have a happy life,

and to be a person, a woman,
who is having influence on the world, and
that you don't have

to follow set rules because it's
not clear what those rules are. So grandma Joe
didn't follow rules.

She stayed up until the
wee hours of the morning to be making things. She was forever making things.

She didn't like housekeeping. And so I really, as a kid,
looked at her house as this

amazing museum where you
could touch stuff because most museums you can't.

I now realize she probably
was a borderline hoarder. And she didn't like to cook--

well, she did, except
when she cooked, she would cook large
amounts of food so she didn't have to cook
about one time a week.

She also had-- a trunk of her
car that was filled with picket signs because she was a devoted
to Union and workers' rights.

So I really saw her passion
coming out in that way. So she was one of my go team.

The other was my other
grandmother, who you could say was, in some ways,
very much a contrast.

She didn't like to
cook either so much. In fact, often went
out to restaurants or we ate deli sandwiches
when we visited with her.

But she was one of the
few medical doctors in the country in the 1920s.

So she went the route
of medical school and practiced well
until the 1970s.

And so she was really a model
of a woman taking a path that wasn't a common path.

And in fact, in the little town
where she and my grandfather set up their practice
in Southeast Missouri,

many of the citizens of the town
thought she was a witch doctor, and so really couldn't believe,
in fact, that she was a doctor.

And I would hear her
talking with her patients. And I really saw kindness and
professionalism, and really

an incredible
professional woman doing her work that was
sometimes ignored or pushed

back on by the people that
she was trying to help. So she's the second member
of my, you go, girl, team.

The third member is my
sister, Simona Frank,

who's 13 years older than I am. And I should tell a little
bit about history here.

So my sister was going to high
school in, roughly, 1961--

is when she graduated. I graduated from
high school in 1974. And if you're aware
of history, that

was a pretty pivotal
era in the United States in terms of women's rights
and agenda expanding

what women could be doing. Roe v Wade was in
the early 1970s.

Title IX, which we've
been celebrating, was also in the early 1970s.

So my sister was
coming of age at a time when there hadn't been
these expanded rights

and access to things,
but that didn't stop her. My sister graduating from
college, took on a job

that no other woman in
the country had taken on. She was with a team of
four other women that

became bank examiners for
the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is a
branch of our US government.

And so I saw in this
individual who I love and love dearly someone who
was doing things

that were not conventional
too, and taking on roles.

So that's the go girl team
that has influenced me. Just as a little
bit of history too--

so this is an ad
that IBM put out, and I'll tell you the
year in just a minute. But you see some pink booties
and some blue booties.

And it says, as things stand,
it doesn't take much guess to which one of these will
grow up to be an engineer.

the cost to society
is enormous because it affects women's career choices
and limits the contributions

they can make. Only 4% of all
engineers are women. Only 13.6% of all math and
science PhDs are women.

And an encouraging
but still low 31.3% of all professional computer
programmers are women.

I have to say-- and I'll tell you the year
that this came out is an ad, and it was a gift from
my dad, actually, to me,

we are up to about 15% of
all engineers being women. So the number has
risen from that 4%.

Unfortunately, the number
of people women in computer science has fallen from 31%.

So that's a declining number. I am happy to report that there
is now more social science--

and some of the work I do,
actually, is in this field for us understanding
why there is this gap

and what things need to
change about the system in order to encourage more
women to become engineers.

So this came out in
1985, this ad of IBM saying, this is an important
area for us to be working in,

and it still is. So that's my second team. OK. So let me introduce you
to my third and final team

that I'm going to talk about,
and that's team kindness. And it's made up of
Bernie Roth, and Ruth

Sheppard-- you might suspect
that she's my mom, she is, and Ed Carrier.

So let me tell you what
that team has been like. So Bernie Roth is a dear
colleague and friend,

and has been since my first day
of stepping on to the Stanford campus some 36 years ago.

And a lesson from
Bernie about kindness is, kindness really needs
to, at first and foremost,

be directed inward too. I think sometimes we're
awfully hard on ourselves

and not really candid
with ourselves. And so that kindness to
ourselves is important.

And for me, with Bernie,
that was, for instance, his inviting me to a yoga
class some 20 years ago.

And I had not done
yoga as a girl from Wisconsin and Michigan. And that's really
become a self kindness

that I practice, maybe
not every day, but quite a few days of the week, in
terms of taking care of myself

both mentally and physically. Another kindness from
Bernie is actually being quite candid with
myself and learning

to be honest about why I'm doing
something, why I'm not doing something, and really not--

to quote Bernie, not
bullshitting myself about my reasons
for doing things. And I learned this through
a series of workshops

that I attended
that Bernie happened to be one of the coleaders on. I've also learned it time
and time again with his book,

which I highly recommend. It's called The Achievement
Habit: Stop wishing, Start Doing, and Take Command of
Your Life by Bernie Ross.

So kindness starts at home and
starts with us as individuals.

Just to illustrate just a little
bit of Bernie's philosophy-- so this is a little card
he gave me at some point

on decision making. And it says, are you happy? And it says, yes, if that's
the way you're going.

And it says, well, then keep
doing what you're doing. And then the other
path is, are you happy?

No. And then it says here, change
something-- oh, no, it says,
do you want to be happy? That's the next question. You're not happy. Is it important to be happy? And if you say--

do you want to be happy? No. You just keep doing the
things you want to be doing. But if you want to be
happy, you change something.

And so that's one of the
backbones, if you will, of his book here.

So that's Bernie with
the self kindness. From my mom, really
recognizing that kindness

can happen in very, very small
ways with our interactions with other people.

And maybe it's
holding a door open or sending somebody
after they've given a talk-- boy, that
talk was really great, thanks

for giving it. In my mother's case, it showed
up in her 30 years of teaching.

See I ended up doing a lot
of what my parents did, an engineer and a teacher, but
it wasn't the original path.

She would-- every night when her
fifth graders left, she would be at the door, and she would
shake individual hands and say,

Ms. Smith, or Mr. Jones,
have a good evening, I look forward to
seeing you tomorrow.

I hadn't realized how
important that little kindness was until after she passed
away a few years ago.

One of her former students
who was probably my age said that made the difference
in him having confidence

to survive fifth grade and
actually go on and become a doctor. So we don't know how
those little kindnesses

impact one another. So that's a lesson from
my mom on kindness.

I would say, from the
last character that's on my go team, Ed Carrier--

Ed's also-- we're
married, and we've been married for 44
years, so a long time.

And I think the lesson there
is that, kindness never goes out of fashion.

those kindnesses
remain important. And whether it's a-- choosing Diet Coke
instead of Diet Pepsi

because that's what he
likes and is available, or leaving a little
mint on the pillow and--

just a lot of little things
that our kindness do accumulate.

So on that team, I
would ask you to think about what kindness is--
and maybe you already

received today, what kindnesses
have you extended to others, and how does that come into
your everyday practice.

With the go, girl
team, a question I should have put
out there would be, whose go, girl
team are you maybe on,

and who's on your go, girl team? So I should say some
caveats with these teams.

Some of these
characters have actually been on various
parts of these teams so they're not exclusive teams.

There are also many, many other
people who are on these teams. So they're not all just
three-person teams.

Some living, some not living,
some much younger than I am,

some much older than I am. And I suspect that
when you think about what are the teams
that are important to you,

they may fall into
these three categories, but there may be
other categories. So for instance, I also
have a team spiritual,

and that's the team
that really helps me think about those
bigger loftier questions,

or the meaning of
my life and God, and what role does God play.

And I also have an
exercise team beyond my doing yoga that gets
me out there hiking

when I think I'm too busy. So really, be also thinking
about, what are your teams,

and whose team are
you playing on? So that's the team part of it. What do you want to
talk about, Robyn?

Or what queries
have been coming in? ROBYN WOODMAN: I love that. We have so many great questions. And I really loved how
you divided that all up.

And I really love team kindness. Team kindness was so great,
especially with Bernie Roth.

So Bernie is a fixture
over in the D school. What a lovely human being. I've gotten to interact
with him a few times,

and every time, it's just
a pleasure and a joy. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yes. ROBYN WOODMAN: So I really
like that Bernie's advice was, be kind to yourself
first, because that's

where it all begins. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. So thank you for that. So, we have some
great questions. It looks like Sandra has
asked a really great question.

She said what if you are alone
and you don't have support? Where are some places maybe that
you could look for your team?

Have you had some
experience where you've found your team or maybe
some sponsorship, or mentorship

reaching out and
attending this webinar is a good starting point of looking
at what resources there are.

There's also finding
like interest, and it could be
hiking, and actually

seeing where the nonprofessional
can also be professional links,

going to women's events. For instance, tonight
we're hosting--

I'm the faculty advisor for
a group called The ME Women's group, and it's a
club, if you will,

or an organization,
of graduate student women in the department that's
been around for 25 years.

And we're hosting
a welcome reception for alumni from
the ME department,

as well as all of
the graduate student women in the department. So be looking for those
events that are happening.

Do you have any
thoughts for her too? ROBYN WOODMAN: I think
that's great advice. And I really like the
advice of not only looking

professionally, and
try not to silo those and make those discrete buckets. But if what you
enjoy doing outside

can also traverse
over to what you enjoy doing professionally,
looking for groups, I totally agree with you.

And then also, I think
that there's something that maybe we get trapped
in ourselves a lot, and we're in our heads and we're
ruminating a lot on things.

And nine times out
of 10, the people that are around you, the
women that are around you, are having those same
thoughts that you are having.

And sometimes it's about just
extending the first word. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: Hi. I'm you here.

Or, I'm not really
sure how to do this, but I'm getting used to it. Or just having that first
word towards someone

could really start that
bridge, building that bridge in a really big way. SHERI SHEPPARD: It also
reminds me of a technique

that we teach in a
series of classes called Designing Your Life.

And there's a Designing
the Professional, that I was originally part
of the teaching team on. And we teach in that
information interviewing.

And the sense of reaching
out to someone to say,

you don't know me. Your life looks interesting. Can I have 15 minutes of
your time to talk about you.

And it's amazing how people
are very receptive in talking about themselves. ROBYN WOODMAN: Absolutely. SHERI SHEPPARD: And part of
my reasons for saying yes to

[LAUGHTER] ROBYN WOODMAN: We
love that you want to talk to us about yourself. Thank you. [LAUGHTER]

SHERI SHEPPARD: And you may
get some no's, but people like to feel like they
have something to give.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Absolutely. SHERI SHEPPARD: Even
for Stanford students, sometimes that's
a big step to say,

I'm going to I'm going
to email somebody, and will they get
back with me, or I'm going to try to call them. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. Putting yourself out
there in that way.

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. I totally agree. I think that's great advice. SHERI SHEPPARD: And it builds on
what you were saying, going in
with this, I've got questions. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. And it's great. And it's OK. And it's not a sign of weakness.

In fact, I think it's a sign of
courage to be able to say that. SHERI SHEPPARD:
That reminds me--

the reaching out, I had not
been in this role very long, being an assistant professor.

And I had the
experience-- every time I would go into
my chair's office, I would come out and go
to the bathroom and cry.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh. SHERI SHEPPARD:
And I'm thinking, nobody else has this experience.

Well, I was at a
conference soon after that, and I was going up
the elevator with another assistant professor
who I admired very much,

I knew her. And I said to her,
Pam, do you ever cry? She goes, I do it all the time.

And we were like-- we hugged
one another because, whoa, we're not alone. ROBYN WOODMAN: See. It's about having
that first word.

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah, yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh, that's
such a great story. Thank you so much for that. That's so great.

And I love how you
were, so honest. You didn't beat around the bush. Do you cry? [LAUGHTER]

Oh, that's so great. OK. Thank you so much for that. We have some great
questions coming in.

Let's see. Laura wants to know,
how do you represent women in the field
of engineering without getting exhausted?

Is it just as subversive
for a woman in engineering to just do the
work without always having to represent women?

SHERI SHEPPARD: Oh,
I love this question because this
particularly annoyed me

for the first 18 years as the
only woman on the faculty. And I don't know if
I was projecting,

but I'd be in a meeting,
only woman there, and people would ask, well,
what do you think, Sheri?

And maybe they were
being kind, but I often interpreted it like, what's
the woman's point of view here?

And I'm only one woman
with one experience. So that was annoying.

And it was also-- I'd only been here
a year or two. And one of my dear
colleagues, I think he thought he was being
kind, but he asked,

what is it like being a
woman assistant professor? And I was stumped
because I know what

it's like being an
assistant professor. How being a woman layers
on that, I'm not sure.

So I think I said, well, I can
answer the question about what I'm experiencing as an
assistant professor,

but I'm not sure it's
unique to me being a woman. So this is where, actually,
getting colleagues,

whether they be in the
sciences or outside, can be really helpful, both
in sharing the workload if you

feel compelled. And I certainly
have, in my career, to be proactive in saying,
yes, I'm going to do the work.

And I see this other burden and
responsibility in figuring out how other women can be at
the table and other diversity

can be at the table. So actually building a network
of other people to say,

could you do this? Or I'm going to do this. And then even
borrowing material.

And then also learning
sometimes you have to say no. And that gets to
our second topic.

But you can't do it all. So you have to preserve
that kindness to yourself

and feeling like, I've
given enough for right now. I can't take on another
speaking engagement

or another op-ed
article to write. So that would be managing
by sometimes saying no too.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Which I think
is a great thing to do. I think when we email back
and forth about possibly

coming here, I'm always very
cognizant of what I'm asking. And understanding
that I'm sending

one email with one
request, but how many are you actually fielding? And so it's really
important for me to--

I want to extend
the grace of saying, it's OK if you can't do
it, I totally understand.

Or, here's the ask. And you don't have to put
together a slide deck. And we really just--

SHERI SHEPPARD: --which is good. ROBYN WOODMAN: Right. Oh, yeah. I mean, anything you have to
put a slide deck for, I'm in. Like, call me up.

[LAUGHTER] Call me up. But just having these
kinds of conversations and letting people into the
background of what's going on,

I think, is one of the
most important things that we can be doing. I just think it's so helpful. SHERI SHEPPARD:
You know, I've also

recognized that I'm not an
expert in women's issues. I mean, that's not
my field of study.

is Londa Schiebinger, who's
over in the history department. And she looks at design from the
perspective of who's included

and who's not included
and how to develop new guidelines to be more
inclusive in thinking

about design. And her website is called
Gendered Innovations. So I will pull Londa into
my conversation of like,

I've been asked to do this. Maybe it's better
that you do it. Or do you have some material
that's fresh and new

that I can pull in? Another really important
colleague of mine has been Carol
Muller, who really

knows the literature on women
and engineering and STEM fields.

And so relying on
Carol if I need-- What are some of the
most recent writings that have been happening? ROBYN WOODMAN: Right.

Right. And that sounds like
team collaboration. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. Yes, you're right. So we don't need another team. [LAUGHTER]

ROBYN WOODMAN: It's always good
to have those collaborators. And I think it's an
important distinction to make just because you are
a woman, or we are women.

It doesn't mean we're going
to speak to everything. It just means we can speak
to what your story is

or what my story is. And that's pretty much-- And I think having that caveat
is a great distinction to make.

It looks like we had a great
comment here from Kavia. "Thank you for sharing your
various names for your support groups.

That makes it easy to
comprehend and realize that we may be overlooking
our cheering squad and thinking we don't have one."

I agree. I mean, it's great. "It can come from
anywhere, and we need to recognize it and
acknowledge it and let

it motivate us and carry us
through our moments of doubts. I just love that concept. Thank you." And she's going to be
sharing it with her daughter

as she's starting her career
as a young student, which is exactly why we
have these sessions. SHERI SHEPPARD: The other
thing I realized in making up

this prompt for here-- This is going to become a
poster in my office, both

so that my students see that
it's not just me-- there's other people being represented
here-- and as a reminder for me

because sometimes, I
have dark days too. And kind of, oh, there's a team. ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh, yeah.

Who is available
on the team today? Yeah. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: Absolutely. Absolutely.

So Sarah had a great question. "Do you have any advice for
raising young women today

or techniques for encouraging
exploration in STEM? SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah.

So I think getting young
women making things

and really using their hands. And making things
ranges from sewing--

I mean, I think sewing
is an incredible activity of going from a
two-dimensional world

to a three-dimensional world
and working inside and outside. So in terms of spatial
reasoning, it's really great.

Also, though,
makerspaces and thinking about what is this electronic
stuff and demystifying that.

And I think there are
a number of camps, for instance, that Stanford
offers in the summertime.

There are also, now, in
Girl Scouts, badges related to technology and engineering.

So that's another chance
to get girls involved. I would also say--

I would say-- And I
actually have a daughter. She's 33. And she didn't go down
the engineering path.

She was a history major
and is the youth librarian at the San Leandro Public
Library across the Bay.

So she found her own path. But exposing girls to
making as well as what

is it to be a modern
woman and that there is that diversity that
includes fancy dresses

as well as blue jeans
when things get messy. I think, also, giving
them some backbone of when

do you push back, when
do you, also, say, I've got an opinion here.

How to, also-- and I think we
see this with our students, women students too--

not fall into the
documentation role in a team or the planning role.

And those are important roles. I don't mean to diminish them. But also having them be able
to say, I can write that code.

Or, I don't know how
to write that code, but I'm going to figure it
out because that's where I want to expand my learning. So a certain level
of, I would say,

assertiveness in all of this. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. Absolutely. Something about your
daughter being a librarian.

I can tell you that the
librarian, for me, was my hero. I loved my librarian every year
because I was the kid that--

I was always reading a
book, and it was my escape. It was also my very safe place.

And I could just like
whip through them, and I would leave the library
with just like stacks. And then the librarian
would pull books for me.
I just felt so taken care of. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. Well, it sounds like similar.

My daughter had an
experience with her librarian that she had from nursery
school through eighth, a woman named Misha.

And Misha would serve
tea in the library too. So there was also this
wonderful community. I would say now, as a librarian,
though, she's also got a grant,

and she installed a
makerspace in the library because really starting to see
how can that place for kids

be about books and
about imagination but also about, how do
you take that imagination

and use a 3D printer, for
instance, or a sewing machine to make it into hardware?

ROBYN WOODMAN: And make it
into something tangible. That's great. SHERI SHEPPARD: So
she's often debugging

things that aren't running, so
playing the technology role. [LAUGHTER] ROBYN WOODMAN: As we all do.

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yes. ROBYN WOODMAN: Regina had
a really great question that came in earlier.

"I really love your
insight about needing to see other ways of
being and working in order to imagine those
other possibilities

for your future career. It strikes me that
not everyone has the opportunity or
opportunities to see what

different careers look like. And in particular, women
may have less exposure to traditionally male careers
or may not see themselves

in these careers. Do you have any tips for
how adult women might get more exposure to different
career possibilities?

And also, what can
we do, as adults, to expose nontraditional career
paths to more young women?"

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. I think that's where this
information interviewing

approach can be helpful-- is identifying some domains. And this is the
exercise we go through

with our students is, where
is a domain that you're curious about? And it may be
medical technologies.

Or it may be transportation. Or it may be senior
care that attracts you

in terms of an area
that you might want to imagine yourself working. And then try to figure out who
some individuals are there.

And I think LinkedIn
has made this easier in terms of scouting
out who's in what area.

And be bold enough to
say, you're interesting. Can I understand more
about what you do?

It's probably harder to
say, can I shadow you? But really helping them talk
to you about, what is your day

like? What are some of
the joys you get? What are some of
the hard points? Are there choices that
you wish you hadn't made

in terms of what you're doing? What education was needed? What education do
you wish you'd had?

So being bold enough to get
out there and ask questions. In terms of role models--

So one of the things I do
with the MEWomen's Group that I mentioned is we
put on a seminar series

every winter quarter called
Women's Perspectives. And it's been around
for about 20 years.

And in the fall, I sit
down with the leadership, the graduate student
women, to brainstorm

on interesting people we
want to have an excuse to invite to campus to talk.

And we really look at diversity
in terms of where in the world they're working, what they're
working on, their age.

We have some women
who come who are in their 30s, some women who
come that are in their 70s. And they tell pretty
different pictures,

depending on their
stage of life-- some who've chosen the academic
route, some who've not, who've gone to government.

We once had a science
writer who had done a PhD in
mechanical engineering. Because like your
question implies,

people are really
hungry for stories and seeing the
diversity of those and seeing the
lumpiness along the way.

So we tell the speakers,
just don't make it all look wonderful because
we really know you've

had some bumps in the road. And sometimes, speakers
will talk about depression

and needing to take breaks
along with success stories.

So we're all hungry for that. And really as a
way of trying on,

that could be a path for me,
or I don't want to go that way. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. I think, also, for
me, a couple of things

are asking people like,
what is your average day look like, because
sometimes, you have in your mind
what that thing is.

But then, in reality,
it's not that thing. And if you get too
far down that path, you're like, oh, I want to--

And maybe you heard someone
say one day like, oh, you're really good at math. You should be an accountant. And you don't really know
what else you want to do,

so you kind of grab onto that. But then you meet an accountant. If you could meet an
accountant and say,

what does your
average day look like, maybe that's not at all
what you want to be doing. SHERI SHEPPARD: And
the physics teacher

might have said to that
student, you're good in math. Do engineering. ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah. 100% And if you don't have
a solid sense of yourself,

you find yourself going towards
that path of something that really isn't meant for you. So I think just being
curious about what

comes natural to
you, identifying what you like to do in a day. And then even like going
to LinkedIn, like you said,

or putting in Google,
I like to do this. What are these careers? Like get basic. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah.

Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: You know. And that's OK. SHERI SHEPPARD: Basic
and also open-minded because some of
those things could

be packaged in job titles
that are new to you.

Yeah. And it's really a changing
landscape in terms of skills and how those get packaged.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Absolutely. And just finding other
people that have-- They're doing things
that you like. And you look at their
job title like, oh,

that's what that job title does. SHERI SHEPPARD: I
mean, the question also brings up this
interesting possibility.

So, I mean, with
students, whether they be undergraduate or
graduate students, we encourage them
to do internships.

And those are really
trial jobs of, what is it like
to be an engineer at Boeing or at a startup?

Or go to a venture capital firm. And they can try them on for
three months or six months

and then come back
and reflect and how does that affect their courses
and where else they might

want to do internships. Why aren't there
adult internships? ROBYN WOODMAN: I
don't know, Sheri.

That's what we need because
they're such low-stakes way, because I think, sometimes,
people will get into things,

and then they're already
concerned about, well, I am already here. And I said this,
but the internship is such a finite,
discrete thing.

Three months. This is what you do. And then you're done. You're like, oh, it was
just like a little buffet, a little sampler platter. Yeah.

I totally agree. Let's have an adult internship. OK. Couple more, and
then we're going

to talk about the yes trap. "What are your go-to resources
for designing your life? What do you tell people?"

SHERI SHEPPARD: Ahh, OK. So one would be
read Bernie's book. ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yep.

The other is Bill Burnett
and Dave Evans have two books out on designing your life.

And it is based on
the series of courses that included Designing
Your Stanford Experience,

that's for graduate students. And so those books
really capture a lot of the tools in thinking
about, what is your worldview?

When you write about
your purpose in life and what you think would
be a fulfilling life,

is that consistent with
writing your work view? And so there's exercises of
writing those and then seeing,

are they consistent
with one another? There's also the strategy of
information interviewing, which

I've already talked about,
where we get students out prototyping, if you will,
possible career paths or job

domains. So that's another part of it. And then the course,
and their book

also gets this idea of
writing an Odyssey plan. And not just writing one of
them but writing three of them.

And each of them need
to be pretty different and still encapsulate your
work and your worldview

and recognizing that
there are different ways to use math in a career.
It could be as an accountant. It could be as an engineer. It could be as a statistician.

There's lots of ways
to use that skill. And so you don't
feel trapped to say,

this is the only path for me. And then the exercise
takes what you

think is the most
cohesive of those three and actually write
a 10-year plan. So you can capture a lot of
those exercises in their books.

ROBYN WOODMAN: OK. Great. Thank you. And the one you held up
was The Achievement Habit-- SHERI SHEPPARD:
--by Bernie Roth. ROBYN WOODMAN: OK. Great.

Excellent. Thank you. SHERI SHEPPARD: OK. Good. ROBYN WOODMAN: All right. Let's see. Durkira said she
loves libraries too,

so there's another
plug for the library. And Laura just wanted
to say, "Thank you for sharing your

I've cried in front of every
male boss I have ever had. And it took me a

be embarrassed about,

but it's an opportunity
to normalize the display of human emotion." I'm here for that as well. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah, yeah.

And I would say I came to
the realization of not being embarrassed that I was crying.

I would actually cry in front
of, particularly, this one chair. And that part of I didn't
want to cry because I

didn't want him to feel bad. But I was past worrying
about him feeling bad. It's how I felt.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I think we spent a lot of time
caretaking other people when,
really, we should just cry. Cry. What do we have? We have cry.

We have adult internships. SHERI SHEPPARD: Right. Yep. ROBYN WOODMAN: We have find
your groups, find your people.

SHERI SHEPPARD: And reach
out to people and say, you're interesting. Can I have 5 or 10
minutes of your time?

ROBYN WOODMAN: Who is
going to say no to that? I agree. OK. Can you tell us
about the yes trap?

SHERI SHEPPARD: OK. So want to talk a little bit
about this idea of a yes trap.

And I've said yes to
many things in life. I said yes to going down
an engineering path.

I said yes when a group
of other professors approached me in my second
year as an assistant professor

here and said, we're
going to put together a proposal for a grant that's
on engineering education.

And at the time, that was
kind of a wacky idea-- that research was supposed
to be about technical things.

My area of work
was in structures and fatigue and fracture
and welded structures.

So I said yes to that. And I said yes to
Professor Kurajian

about teaching that night class. And I'm glad I said yes. But what I have gotten
stronger of believing

is, when you say
yes, what is the no? And so I made a mistake when
I said yes to engineering

because I said no to music. And my conception of
music at that time is I can do it
professionally, or I'm not

going to do it at all. So the yes wasn't a mistake,
but the no was a mistake.

And so I brought
Gertrude, my ukulele, because I'm back to
actually making music now

after many years. And so that no has turned
into a reframed way of being.

So that was too stark of a no
at the time when I was starting college. The second example
about saying yes

to the colleagues who
approached me about becoming part of this big NSF grant--

that my administration
was really discouraging me from doing, saying, this really
is not a good thing for you

to do, was I did not say no soon
enough to all the other things

I was doing. So for about 20 years,
I kept a dual life

going of doing research
in engineering education along with doing research
on fatigue and fracture.

And to be perfectly
honest with you, it was exhausting
because I was trying to be a major player in
two different fields.

And I really wish I had
said no sooner after I'd gotten my feet under me about
engineering education to say,

I can put that down. I've done good
work there, and I'm moving on to something else.

So those are examples
of really needing to think about yes, but
at the same time, what

is the no associated with it? In thinking about,
also, saying yes--

I recognize I want to make
sure that I get these points-- that sometimes, I say yes
because nobody else volunteers.

I'll be at a table,
and somebody needs to organize the next meeting
or write up what we just did

or bring in some
other resources. and I, often, after
that awkward pause,

because I confuse quantity
of work with quality of work. And maybe saying
more things that I'm

doing that I've said yes to,
it makes me feel more important or seem more important
because of all of that

yes that I've done. So I've learned to
recognize that those are not

good reasons for saying
yes to something. And Bernie, if you read
in his book, he'll say,

"All reasons are bullshit." And that's a quote
from Bernie in here.

I have come up with a strategy,
though, of a set of questions I ask myself before I say yes.

And I've got them
listed here to make sure that I've got them all. And then I'll loop
back to saying,

why did I say yes to you? So the first is, can I do
what is being asked of me?

Is it in my wheelhouse, so to
speak, of things that I can do. Will I do it, or will I
just let a deadline pass

and just have said yes but
not actually come through with what's being asked?

Will I be happy doing
what is being asked of me? And I think that one is
increasingly on my list.

And that happiness
includes, who am I going to be working with on this? Are these really
cool people, that

just there's going to be joy in
hanging out with them in doing this and interacting with them?

And this one has become
more and more key. The fourth one is, will
I be learning something when I'm doing what
is being asked for me?

If it's the same old,
same old, then there's not going to be a learning
opportunity there.

And I've realized that
I'm a learning addict. That idea of being in a field
where I don't know all of it

and that messiness of
learning is important for me in terms of
a source of energy.

Fifth question. Will somebody else benefit
from my saying yes? So really thinking about
a larger community--

graduate students I've had,
undergraduates I've had, colleagues. And if I say yes to
this, is it going

to help somebody else's
career or pathway? Would somebody else
benefit from my saying no?

And so recognizing that maybe
that talk that I've been asked to give, I could do it.

I could learn. But actually, a junior colleague
might benefit more career-wise by my saying no and
my recommending them

as a good person to take it on. And then seventh. And this is probably
the hardest one for me

that I still struggle with. What will I put down
if I pick this up? So recognizing getting
by on five hours of sleep

is not a reasonable thing to
do in life by just continuing to pile more and more on.

So going back to your
asking me to do this. Can I do what is
being asked of me?

I think I can probably
talk about myself.  Will I do what is
being asked for me?

Yes, because Matt Harvey was one
of the people who suggested it. And I really respect
Matt, and I'm

going to come through for him
when he asks, and I say yes. Will I be happy doing
what is being asked of me?

Yes. Matt is a fun
person to work with, and our first
engagements were fun. So I thought, yeah,
I'm going to be happy.

Will I be learning
something new? And that one was interesting
because I went back and looked

at the recordings of
the prior two speakers, and I really loved that
each, in their unique way,

personalized it. And it didn't have
PowerPoint slides. So for me, it was
a challenge of how

to tell my story in a way that
was engaging, that brought in some art. So I was learning a new way
of thinking about my story,

so that was cool. Will someone else benefit
from my saying yes? I hope all of you.

And I've benefited
again from thinking about how I package or tell
my story in a different way.

Will someone else benefit
from my saying no? I actually thought about
this and who else could I recommend, but decided not.

Because it was kind
of a short time frame. And a lot of people are busy
getting the quarter started.

And then what will I put
down if I pick this up? I have to admit I didn't
put anything down.

And I had lots of fun
preparing this, so it was good. ROBYN WOODMAN: Oh, thank you. SHERI SHEPPARD: Sure.

ROBYN WOODMAN: I
love that checklist. And thank you so much. SHERI SHEPPARD: Sure. ROBYN WOODMAN: It was nice
to see that in action. And kind of how you
thought about it as you

went through it. And now that you have told
your story in this way, do you have other
opportunities or applications

that you can see
this applying to? SHERI SHEPPARD: Telling
the story in this way? ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah.

Maybe for the ME group. SHERI SHEPPARD: Maybe for
the ME, maybe for, actually, my research team.

Because there's about
10 people in that team. And they're asking questions
about what's their pathway.

And I think I do recognize
some of them look at me, you're this

you've always been that. And it may open up a

linear path at all.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah, for sure. And I think that a lot of us

And when it doesn't,
inevitably, look like that, then we're comparing our insides

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: And
that's where we cry. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah.

SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: The

Thank you so much. And it's always a great

I admire and, I think, is so interesting. And for you to come on and tell
your story behind the story,

I definitely took a lot
of nuggets from that. Absolutely. And I saw a lot of overlap, too.

So thank you for that. SHERI SHEPPARD: And I
would say, this career path is ever-evolving.

You acknowledged in my
title that I've retired. I'm actually on 50% recall.

For the next two years,
Stanford has this program. ROBYN WOODMAN: What
does that mean? SHERI SHEPPARD: I'm
struggling with that.

Because I'm struggling
with it in 3 ways. It's 50% what's the number.

I usually work 50 to 60 hours. So is it 50% of that, or is it
50% of a normal 40-hour a week

job? So that's the first part. The second struggle is when I
figure out that number, what

to keep in and what to put out? Really acknowledging this is an
opportunity to say what would

I like to have stickiness here
at Stanford after I'm gone. ROBYN WOODMAN: Right. SHERI SHEPPARD: So who
are my new partners,

or what are partnerships
I want to strengthen? So that other people are
taking things I've started

and continuing them. What are things that
only I care about? And I could put them down
and no one would notice.

And then, what are
new things I want to be taking on
that I will continue even after I'm fully retired?

So that's the second
part of the struggle. And then the third part is I
realize I cannot care at 50%.

That when I do something,
I'm caring 110%. And so really recognizing with
whatever I'm doing that smaller

set, that I've got the
space to really put my heart and soul and hands into it.

And so I think that's really
the hardest one is recognizing that I care a lot. ROBYN WOODMAN: Right.

And since you're
going to care 110%, you need to be especially
specific about what

you are choosing to care 100%. OK. SHERI SHEPPARD: Yeah. ROBYN WOODMAN: That
makes a lot of sense. SHERI SHEPPARD: So that's where
I'm playing a lot more music.

I'm doing more writing
kind of in the op Ed area. After a lot of experiences,

I'm working on consolidating
a lot of research that I've done for

in terms of other
papers or a book. So it's a fun stage
and a scary stage

to think about what's next. ROBYN WOODMAN: Right. Because it's a stage
that, obviously, you've never been in before. And so now, you're figuring it
out about what that actually

means. SHERI SHEPPARD: And this is

keep going, and you keep going. But I've been reaching
